addressleaf.section: A Monsieur Monsieur de Sidney chevalier et Governeur de la ville de Vlissingnes

page.lettertext:
fol.160r
S
r
Thomas Bodley to S
r
Robert Sydney
Upon the receat of yo
r
L
dships
letter of
e 12 of
this p
nt
, I acquainted
e
Councel
both w
t
the
teno
r
of her
Ma
ties
letter, and w
t
yo
r
L desire to
be excused upon it: w
ch
they tooke in good part
in respect of yo
r
L. but disliked
Count Maurice
for detracting
e time in sending
e two compa-
nies of their owne nation. For had they bin sent,
as it was resolved, yo
w
might well have for-
boaren
e sending of any c
o
pany. When that
answear is come hither, w
ch
is signified by her
Ma
tie
to be sent unto them heere, they are fully
purposed to replie againe, w
t
a good remonstr
a
ce.
For in truth it is needefull. And for mine
owne part, because I see
e inconvenience
at is
like to ensewe of these crosse proceedinges of
S
r
Edward Norreis
, I will doe
at in duty perteneth
to my place, both by advertising home, and by
telling S
r
Edward my frindly opini
o
: so as I may
answear all heereafter, whatsoever shall befalle
between her Hig
nes
and this c
o
trey. I doe onely
attend
e Countes coming hither, w
ch
I hope will
be to day, or to morrowe at
e furthest, and
then I will intreat him to take some better course
for disposing of yo
r
cornet in some other garrison.
For mater of newes, all
at I can signifie, is
an enterprise
at was intended to be perfourmed
as yesterday by
e
Count Overstein
and
S
r
Francis Vere
upon
Straelen
in Guelderland, a
place of small importance, but yet held w
t
a
garrison, and, as it is thought, a very good booty
for
e souldiers.
I have no other mater, but to
wishe yo
r
L. actions all happy successe. Fr
o
the
Hage. A
p
16. 1591.
Yo
r
L. Wholy at co
m
aundem
t
. Tho. Bodley.
